Review_body: It's a fight, it's a masculine fight incarnated by this eternal struggle that men have to endure against nature  it's nature against culture, culture as civilization, this assemblage of whatever rises us above the bestial state. And "Deliverance" is about this fight, in three rounds, ending with a split decision.The first round is won by men, those politicians and businessmen who decided to terminate a natural setting for improving the lives of some bourgeois citizens. A beautiful river condemned to become a common lake, for no other specific reason than to assess the almighty power of men on the face of the Earth. This project scandalizes Lewis, Burt Reynolds, who takes his friends to a last canoe ride, to celebrate the swan song of a natural setting. A setting raped by men, but that these men will try to honor with respect, like three civilized men. But this is nature, not civilization, and nature is about survival and doesn't give a damn about respect, honor, or dignity. And the natural setting will become their hellish nightmare, and if men rape nature symbolically, unfortunately, nature doesn't give a damn about symbols Lewis, is the one who enthusiastically embraces the call of the wild, like a fish in water, and the same can't be said for Bobby, Drew and Ed, Ned Beatty, Ronny Cox and Jon Voight as the straight men of a tragicomedy where nature has the good laughs and where Bobby will pay the most humiliating price. These men are so normal, so indeed civilized, that we do feel they will have to face a natural adversary incarnated by this wild river. And the iconic beauty of that film is that nature will be incarnated in its most savage and bestial way, through a population that lived in a world so closed, that it inspired the lowest instincts, starting by the most blasphemous one: incest.It's not surprising that the movie indirectly features incest in its first scene: through the unforgettable hybrid hillbilly who plays one of the most memorable cinematic instrumental duets ever  The 'Duelling Banjos' still resonate in my mind as the hymn announcing a coming battle of men against the elements, against God, nature, give it a name  but the scene is so cheerful, so full of joy and energy that you forget its most important aspect: a warning, a warning about a population where common laws are not respected; after all, isn't the incest, the cardinal sin on which the whole human civilization was based? The first setting is obviously made of doors that open the gates to hell, a hell where there's no God, no rules, except the one of the strongest.And this is how the D of "Deliverance" became the epitome of cinematic "Disturbingness", because it depicted one of the most difficult scenes to watch but still extremely eloquent about the  ways, bestiality choose to assert its power. The way these hillbillies acted had nothing to do with sexuality, it's a rape yes, but more a disgusting affirmation of power that puts men at the same level of animals, even lower. Animals prove their power by the same act, the hillbilly did, and it's not a coincidence that he wanted him to imitate the sound of an animal during that moment. Nothing sexual, no fantasies, living like an animal is acting like one, and the only way to get rid of this scum, was to ruthlessly kill him. Natural selection, an eye for an eye. At the end of the second round, it's a tie.And to understand the beauty of civilization is to understand its weakness. Despite all the pain, Ed and especially Bobby went through; they were still debating about the gravity of killing. Ed, who couldn't kill a deer, climbed a dangerous cliff to kill the bad guy, but still couldn't shoot him at the crucial moment. Because 'an eye for an eye' is still nature talking and the law is here not to comfort this nature, but to correct it. Lewis asks if someone knows about the laws, this is an important scene, because it means that for these men, killing still means going against their nature, they have to respect some rules and act only in self defense. Nature affects their acts but not their reactions.It's a pity that the film is only remembered as the one which features a male rape. This rape is not gratuitous, it's a powerful and meaningful scene that illustrates our whole fears, as civilized men: meeting nature in its cruelest and less empathetic form. And this is why "Deliverance" is one of the greatest thrillers ever produced by the 'New Hollywood' wave (no pun intended), because it explores one of our deepest fears : being men in a hostile environment that wouldn't even care if you were a hopeless child, and encountering the nightmarish incarnations of soulless humans. "Deliverance" warns about the death of nature, but also the death of humanity. Both are in danger, and both help each other. Men can still respect nature and win over the elements, and nature can inspire men some instincts that save them in extreme situations. Not a pessimistic film, and what a thriller! And more than a thriller, "Deliverance" is just one of the 'great films'. I don't necessarily know what a great movie is, but if I consider Howard Hawks' definition : it's a great film if you can think of three good scenes and no bad ones  well, we have the mountain climbing, the disturbing "squealing like a pig" scene, unforgettable, and the sumptuous and exciting 'Duelling Banjos'. The sound of the banjos that immortalized the symbiosis of men in nature and nature in men. Because the relationship between these two fighters can also be made of male camaraderie, and a complementarity that leads from hell to deliverance.

Deliverance is one of the best movies to come out in the 1970's. I really like this film not only because this movie could end up as a reality for some people, but it possesses what most modern films don't have: character development. The opening scenes and the dueling banjos scenes really told us which personality each of the four main characters have.This movie has a simple storyline. It is about four guys who take a canoe trip down a Georgia river before it is turned into a reservoir.The acting is just brilliant. I can't say anything bad with Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty, and Ronny Cox. They certainly delivered the goods.Of course, I know everyone has heard about the "abduction" scene. It is very well-made and would invoke terror into the audiences of the 1970's. That and the dueling banjos scenes were my favorite of this film.Overall, this a very good, haunting, mesmerizing film. I must also mention this has very good cinematography and good camera shots. I rate this film 9/10.

This film is probably notorious, or infamous rather, for one scene only. It's one of those movies that is always followed by a bad impersonation upon the mentioning of the title. Perhaps like Dirty Harry and 'Are you feeling lucky punk?'. I will try to avoid using the line 'Squeal like a pig' in this review, even though I just did. I should also mention that the film is also forever associated with the Duelling Banjos scene with just about every generation. But I must stress that those who often try to be clever by mimicking both these unique, little features have probably never even scene the film.Four naive city boys take a break from playing golf and decide to canoe down the Cahulawassee River before the valley is flooded into a huge reservoir. It's not their territory, but their leader Lewis Medlock (Burt Reynolds, looking like Steven Seagal's long-lost twin brother) arrogantly assumes that he can deal with any challenge that comes his way. His friends Ed, Bobby and Drew (Jon Voight, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox) reluctantly follow him, despite having their own doubts.The first day of the trip goes fine, but on the second morning Ed and Bobby stop to rest by a small stream. There they are approached by a couple of disgusting mountain men, that are not quite as close to the mutants seen in Wrong Turn but are grotesque nonetheless. Despite their attempts at keeping the peace, the yokels strap Ed to a tree and force him to watch Bobby being raped. Even though I have never witnessed something like this, it's a horribly realistic scene and Ned Beatty does it very well, he must have some guts to do a such a scene in this; his first movie.Lewis shows up in the nick of time and kills one of the yokels but the other escapes. Drew is the only one who thinks that they should take the matters to the police and ends up having a sort of breakdown. In their attempts to escape the scene they crash the canoes and Lewis ends up with a nasty compound fracture. This leaves Ed as the only one capable of hunting down the remaining hillbilly who is preying upon them from the cliff-tops.It's a slow moving film that doesn't focus on the action so much as the horrors taking place in such a tranquil location. John Boorman's widescreen photography beautifully captures the Southern wilderness and comes across as rather haunting without resorting to cheap, slasher movie techniques. Boorman has spent half of his career on a high and the other half languishing in crappiness of Zardoz, Exorcist 2 and the horribly misjudged Excalibur. He has left a lasting impression filmmakers despite his failings.Deliverance is not for everyone and I certainly cannot recommend it to those who are only used to quick-fix MTV movies. But it is still a carefully measured, thought-provoking film.

Review title: This movie truly delivered. A masterpiece of a thriller.
Review_body: It was shaping up to be the perfect weekend for a group of friends from Atlanta. Not only, they get to see the unbelievable natural beauty of the Cahulawassee River before it's turned into one huge lake, they also will get to canoe in it. However, things took a horrible wrong turn in the riverside, as the peaceful natural visit, turn into a deadly game of life or death, when the group find themselves, face to face, with a few unwelcoming locals, mountain men. This is the story of 'Deliverance', a movie that will leave you, with goosebumps. Without spoiling the movie, too much, you would think, a movie like this would stop people, from ever go river-canoeing in the American back-country, ever again. However, surprisingly, this wasn't the case, as the movie had a mostly positive effects on communities in Rabun County, where most of this film was shot. Local sites like Clayton, GA saw an increased in tourism by tens of thousands, just to go river-canoeing. Some tourists even built vacation and second homes around the area's lakes and riverbeds, just take in the beautiful sights. I can see, why, the movie does have gorgeous shots of the location from cinematographer, Vilmos Zsigmond. It even, make me, want to move there, at one time. I doubt the country people, there would complain. For the most part, the majority of locals around there is happy for the film, bringing businesses to their small towns, yet there is others, that still find resentment at how they were portrayed in this movie. I don't blame them. I would, too, be, a bit angry, if my neighborhood was portray as stupid, inbred, rapist, hillbillies. However, I would also be bit cheerful to see money, being pour into my communities, than nothing at all. It's a double edge sword. A Catch 22. Another thing that, probably made the locals, really happy, is the environmental protection message of the film. The opening text, really spells it out, on why author James Dickey was upset, with the lack of conservation in America in the 1970s. Still, it doesn't explain, why, during production of the film, James Dickey showed up inebriated and got into a bitter argument with producer-director John Boorman, for rewritten Dickey's script, when barely anything major was change. In my opinion, the film seem, very accuracy to the source material, but somehow, Dickey didn't see it, that way. It's suck to hear that both men got in a brief fistfight, which cause the director to have a broken nose, and four of his teeth shattered. Thank goodness, the two reconciled before the end of production and became good friends. It even cool to see that Boorman gave Dickey a cameo role as the sheriff. That was pretty nice for him to do, seeing how they hate each other, months earlier. Anyways, the film was a critical success with viewers, even being nominated for awards, despite having a notorious rape scene. Yes, I know, that this is a tough film to praise to anyone, due to the subject matter; and I wrestled with my own feelings for it long after seeing it, but I believe 'Deliverance' is still a movie, worth seeing after all these years, even parts of the film is a bit dated with its depiction of 1970s southerners. After all, it's still is a gripping, absorbing action-adventure film, full of fine actors, whom, for the most part, did one hell of a job, making the nightmarish sequences of the film, seem really intense. As much as I love Burt Reynolds, badass, presence as outdoorsman, Lewis Medlock with him, doing his own stunts. Mad props goes to Jon Voight for similarly doing his own stunts, but also portraying the everyman, Ed Gentry, in this encounter. The struggles of him, having to kill, is, a wonderful depiction, that most people would have, if face, with survival. Also, I have to give credit to Ned Beatty even if his character, was somewhat of a jerk. The viciously targeting and humiliated that the actor has to go, through for his film debut, was courageous. He also almost drown in other scenes. Most actors at the time, would had turn down the role, as a defenseless coward. Likewise, I have to say, Ronny Cox as Drew Ballinger was also good, even if he's not that memorable, outside of the famous "Dueling Banjos" moment. Just the sheer fact that both the hillbilly kid, (Billy Redden) & himself made it seem like they can play the banjo, when in truth, they couldn't play a tune, was impressive on its own. Honestly, I don't care, if there is a copyright dispute on how, originally, create the song. All, I know, is that it's one of the best tunes in American Cinema. Even today, when I hear banjoes. I have to think, about padding faster. That's how much of an impressed, that tune, has on people. It has often be looked upon as a philosophical or mythical allegory of man's psychological and grueling physical journey against the unknown, both within the conflicts of man vs man, and man versus nature. Overall: I love that this movie tests the character's personal values & exhibiting the conflict between country & city. I also like how the movie ends with the flooding of the valley. It alludes to the bible, when it comes to the purification and cleansing within of the sins of the world. Only to find out that not all sins can be washed away. It's a very powerful message. I also the movie leave open questions, like whether or not, they did the right thing. Did they kill the right person or not? Did one of them, really got killed? In the end, it's left to the audience to decide. Overall: while, this movie can be slow at times due to pacing. It's one film, worth paddling to. Its need to be seen. It's that damn good.

Four city slickers head for an adventure in the wilds and get more than they bargained for. On the plus side, the film has good cinematography and there is the memorable "Dueling Banjos" sequence that became a hit on the pop charts. On the negative side, the acting is not very good, the direction is lacking, the characters are poorly developed, and the last part of the film goes on too long. Pretty much everyone overacts. Beatty makes his film debut at age 35 and gets to squeal like a pig. Boorman makes the whitewater scenes exciting but his direction is marred by sloppy execution of the story and his tendency to overuse closeups.

Review title: Burt Should Have Won The Oscar
Review_body:
I have restarted rewatching all of Burt Reynolds movies in order, and I just watched Deliverance (1972)When Burt Reynolds died, based on the reports, you would think he only made 3 movies. Deliverance, Smokey & The Bandit and Boogie Nights, as they were what was all that seemed to get mentioned in reports and social media posts.Filmed on location along the Chatooga Rivet, with a budget of $1.8 million dollars.
Deliverance is not only one the of the 1970's best movies, it is an absolute classic, a damn near perfect movie. Almost 5 decades later, it still holds up as a challenge to a man's thoughts about survival and his theory of masculinity.It is beautifully filmed, all of the actors are amazing and the score is eerily haunting!!A great movie for me is one that does not end with the credits, but stays with you, and I'm always haunted for a while after watching Deliverance (Joker recently had the same effect) too many movies these das are designed to amuse or entertain for 90 minutes then leave you unmoved, uninvolved and unsatisfied. This one poses deep and moral problems for each of its 4 central characters as from the action. Deliverance does not attempt to answer questions. The right or wrong of what the 4 city boys do is left unresolved.Burt did not bat an eye lid when he was told he would be second billed, and Jon Voight would be paid double what Burt was, and received top billing. For his part, Burt was paid $50,000 (much less than the $26,000 per week he was receiving for the TV show Dan August at the time) for three months work, but he knew what an opportunity this was for his career, which he referred to at the time "3 steps below actually mattering" he knew that his performance here, would expose his talent to the world and change his career forever.Look at the scene where Lewis saves the team from the mountain men. He takes command of a dangerous situation and delivers a powerful monologue in the middle of the woods. It is a sensational piece of acting. All of the actors are great, but Burt really rose up and dominated every scene during the first half of the movie.The success of the movie is not all down to Burt of course. The story is compelling and the filmmaking superb, but the key ingredient in Deliverance is Burt Reynolds. I personally think he should have won the Oscar that year.Deliverance was only nominated for 3 Academy Awards. Best Editing, Best Picture and Best Director losing all 3 to Cabret, The Godfather and Bob Fosse respectively. I'm amazed none of the cast or the cinematographer got a nomination.Deliverance was the 3rd highest grossing movie of 1972, with $46 million at the domestic box office

True masterpiece genuinely done; very dark adventurous story about a group of men that are stuck in a situation after some creepy guys do some awful things and things spiral more from there! The sound editing & cinematography alone make this a wonderful experience along with a great cast!I thoroughly enjoyed this menacing adventure; I'm sure it was difficult to make too. Movies aren't made like this anymore, so it's definitely nice to see this gem.

The film is still so incredibly good, even by today's standards, that I can only imagine what it must have been like at the time of release. A fantastic story with very good actors to ensure credibility. The rape scene must have been very controversial back in 1972, and might even be today. It was very well done, though, but must have raised more than just a few eyebrows back then. What follows, is a fast-paced action thriller that literally plummets the characters into the deep end.The setting in nature was also quite spectacular, with beautiful scenery.

"Deliverance" is an Adventure - Drama movie in which we watch a group of friends going on a canoeing trip that will never forget in the Cahulawassee River.I liked this movie because despite the fact that it is an old movie, it is still considered a masterpiece. I understand why due to the fact that it has a nice, interesting and full of suspense plot well-combined with some very good scenes and some very good interpretations too. The direction which was made by John Boorman was simply outstanding and he presented very well the difficulties that these people had to go through but also the the whole adventure behind the canoeing trip.

Review title: Backwoods bromance: when Homer met Gomer...
Review_body: Before BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN or JEREMIAH'S JOHNSON, there was- DELIVERANCE. Like both BROKEBACK MOUNTAIN and JEREMIAH'S JOHNSON, DELIVERANCE is a backwoods bromance that was well ahead of its time. Four city slickers- the ever-so-Butch Burt Reynolds (who was a PLAYGIRL centerfold), Ronnie Cox (who sports the manliest monicker of them all), Ned Beatty, and Jon Voight- head into the mountains lookin' for Love. They find it when they run into some head-huntin' hillbillies, but not before they stop at a roadside zoo and Cox engages in a duet with a cute little in-bred porch monkey. They push on, stroking their way downriver until Beatty and Voight hook up with a couple of good ol' boys looking for a quick shotgun wedding. Beatty and one of the crackers engage in a bit of mountain man foreplay and are just about to consummate their relationship when they experience a bit of Burt Reynolds interruptus. The second cracker, who's tied Voight to a tree (we'll call this one Oddest Tool, because he not only looks like the cannibal necropheliac, but also sports only 5 teeth- 2 in his mouth and 3 in his pocket), parts company with them at this point. Later, he and Voight get together again, whereupon Oddest cries, "Thou hast cleft my heart in twain!" (That's from Willie Shakespears's OMELET, by the way.) In all seriousness, though, DELIVERANCE is a powerful piece of work and the performances to a man are award-worthy. The lament of the Burt Reynolds character echoes to this day. From James Dickey's novel: "The world is easily lost." Truer words were never spoken.

Four city men go on a canoe trip to some river in the middle of nowhere. Everything starts nice, with banjo playing and all, but the problems start when two unfriendly local men start having a little fun with two of the canoe guys.The Deliverance is an amazing thrilling adventure flick.Jon Voight plays Ed, Burt Reynolds plays Lewis, Ned Beatty plays Chubby and Ronny Cox plays Drew.They all do a great job in their roles. The movie is a classic.It keeps the suspense on all the time. Totally worth watching, at least once.The Deliverance is something you won't easily forget.And people, remember; Nobody can beat the river.

Has this movie had a massive impact on society as we know it? You Bet.I'm sure my family are one of millions who hum the banjo theme passing through crappy looking towns or say something similar to us 'this place looks a bit deliverency' and for good reason.This movie was amazing, drumming up solid tension and full of brilliant performances.However for a newer audience they would struggle to feel the same engagement that past audiences enjoyed when this film was released.It is one of the great films that has suffered as society has moved on to a more complicated, pack lots of punches type of entertainment.Its not a criticism of the film and it is definitely worth a watch, but for newer viewers just wind back your expectations a little and you should enjoy it.

Review title: Insanely disturbing, survival movie. It will change ur perception about human nature.
Review_body:
I first saw this on a vhs in the 90s, then on a vcd in 2006 n finally on a blu-ray. It's an extremely disturbing film especially the scene with Ned Beatty. One of the best backwoods/survival film of all time.
The film's awesome scenery, the sounds of birds, reptiles n insects n the gushing wild rivers combined with the absence of civilization are characters themselves.
We get to see Jon Voight doing some daredevil rock climbing and Burt Reynolds in his sleeveless t shirt flaunting biceps.
John Boorman has created one of the best movies based on James Dickey's novel. Indeed an influential movie. The banjo scene n the music is terrific.

***SPOILERS***   ***SPOILERS*** Packed with memorable moments (such as the quote above, immortalized by Primus), Deliverance tells the story of four guys who take a trip to the wild woods to go white water rafting and get away from the big city for a while only to find that their fun soon takes a bad turn. This is not a Hollywood film. There are virtually no special effects whatsoever, the setting is extremely realistic, and nothing at all is sugarcoated or made pretty. The city boys look like city boys, and even the tough guy Louis, portrayed with precision by Burt Reynolds, is clearly at the mercy of the wild on this trip. This is a perfect example of a what-if film. What if a few friends went river rafting in an area of the woods that none of them were familiar with, and ended up desperately trying to avoid being tried and convicted for murders that they were forced to commit to save their own lives?There is clearly a very strong element of the film that deals with societal and class structure and the relationship (or lack thereof) between rural and urban peoples. When the four guys arrive in the woods early in the film, they clearly do not quite know how to interact with the people who live out there, and they speak to them as though they are unsure whether they will understand or be able to communicate. This communication block is most memorably illustrated in the dueling banjoes scene, in which they are trying to gas up the car and truck and get someone to drive the vehicles downriver for them. While Drew and the obviously inbred and probably mentally deficient boy on the porch are dueling with their guitar and banjo (one of the best scenes in the film), Louis is having some difficulty buying the gas, and Bobby makes a comment about genetic deficiencies and how pathetic it all is. When the boy turns away from Drew, who had offered to shake his hand after their stupendous jam session, Bobby tells him to give the kid a couple bucks, knowing that none of them are quite sure how to react.
This is the kind of thing that we see in Deliverance that sets up so much of the tension that is to follow. This great scene where a lot of fun was had (including the funniest 'redneck dancing' scene until O Brother, Where Art Thou?) ended with everyone awkwardly unsure what to do around each other. These people are apples and oranges, and they live by completely different rules of life. The people that Louis, Bobby, Drew and Ed encounter in the hills grew up separated from modern society and modern laws, and live by the rules of nature, which do not include thou shalt not kill. Confused by their awkward behavior, the four friends set out on the river, hoping for the weirdness to end and for the adventure to begin.(spoilers) When they are briefly separated from each other and Ed and Bobby run into the hillbillies beside the river who quickly turn unpleasant, the uncertainty about the way that these people live - which was established by the scene above - comes into play to create the most tension during the scene. I think that a good sign of a quality thriller like this is that the tragic element of the film, namely the assaults and actual murders, takes up a very small amount of screen time but remain some of the most memorable parts of the film. There is no gratuitous violence here, it's all there for an obvious purpose and it achieves a startlingly powerful effect.
The move is about the violent clash of two very different kinds of people, and what can happen when they inadvertently find themselves at war with each other. The trip down the rest of the river after the assault, which takes up the majority of the film, delivers some spectacularly effective tension, and keeps you on the edge of your seat while not bombarding you with so much happening that you become numb. It is surprisingly effective when we find out that Ed may very well have killed the wrong man up there on the cliff, and the tension in the film doesn't even let up when the three surviving members of the team reach the bottom of the river, because they deliver a questionable explanation to the police about what happened up there on the river and why the deputy's brother-in-law is missing.This is a very disturbing film, which is a testament to its success, because it's pretty obvious that a film like this is meant to shake people up a little bit. The hillbillies are the human (i.e. more realistic) version of the sub-human rednecks seen in childish but fairly similar films like Gator Bait and Gator Bait 2, neither of which could possibly ever be compared to a timeless film like Deliverance. When we follow these four men through their fateful weekend in the woods, the natural element is so real and we get to know the men so well and in such a subtle fashion that it's almost like we, as individuals of the audience, are really a fifth member of the team. It's not often that a film is able to come across that way.

Review title: 4 friends tested to the limits of survival. Hardhitting and gutwrenching at times, sad and repulsive at other moments. Still a very impressive movie. Superb acting!
Review_body: 4 friends are making a kanoo trip down a dangerously wild river. The river ain't their worst enemy though, some crazed locals are. Will they survive the violent confrontation? True to life characters struggle with dignity and loyalty in this story, when they are put under pressure, losing their last bit of civilized behaviour.You wont feel cheery after watching "Deliverance". It is definitely NOT your standard "fun" thriller. Hardhitting and gutwrenching at times, sad and repulsive at other moments. There is one particularly repulsive male rape scene that I just cant stand to watch. I skip it, because that particular rape scene is portrayed so accurately and viciously, that even after having watched this movie numerous times I still get sickened by it.The overall feeling of this story is one of increasing despair and grief, although there is some uplifting struggle for survival at the core of this story to be found as well. That uplifting struggle to survive, is what makes this story so thrilling and attractive to be watched again and again. Very impressive movie, with great acting performances. They dont make many great psychological thrillers like these anymore.

Here was a film where action spoke louder than words. Yes I know the dueling banjo's is the highlight of this movie. So we got that out the way. What was surprising, was that this was Beatty's first movie, and the performance he delivers at the wincing pathetic overweight coward, of the four friends was so believable, and colorfully creatives, the makings of a true actor. The other three of course, who of course aren't nobody's deliver good performances too, but it was Beatty's here that stayed with me as one of the humiliated and raped victims of two rednecks yokels having some fun, which soon backfires nastily, yet really the violence here was kept to a minimum, it almost had me pi..ed to be honest, which as revenge fare, with more blood, it would of been better, as from the viewers point, to really see these fu..ers get what they deserved. Yes, I'm saying these two really deserved to die, for what they did as fun loving friends, Reynolds, Beatty, Voight, and Cox, the not so fortunate one, who I liked too, weren't hurting anybody and were just out to have a good time. I've read the script, which I must say, you should look up, as just for description. The movie moves at such a nice (some impatients out there, would say a grinding) pace, which I liked, though I guess evben I was slightly irked at this factor, but it made the film more real. What also impressed me was the aftermath, after committing the murders of the yokels, how they dealed with it, and conspired to cover the truth, where in the real world, is how you do it, or how you answer under pressure, when faced with authorities. Yet, still in this situation, I don't really think you could get away squeaky clean, and too these two these creepy yokel cops smelt a lot of suspicion. The last scene with Voight, lying next to his wife on his return home, was almost eerie, in light of what he's been through. On the whole, Deliverance is a one of those olden golden hits, that leaves it mark, with few other classic 70 stuff.

Classed along with Craven's Last House On The Left, this honestly should have been entitled Last Applachian On The Left, in its attempts at exploitation of the "standard" American male. However, its elevation of a classic stereotype-that of the hillbilly (or, if you prefer, Appalachian American) it cheapens itself even further.I don't know which I dislike more about this film; the veneration of a bad stereotype, or the graphic way in which this movie tries, but fails, to shock its audience. The tactics are cheap, the set up is obvious, and the ending is completely predictable.Frankly, I have never understood the draw this movie has, except for the homo-repressed nature of most white bread over christianized American males. They WANT to see this movie, and like to watch this type of antics.Oh, there are stunning visuals, some beautiful scenery, and it was directed quite well, but it's crap, and always has been.It rates a 2.2/10 from...the Fiend :.

In the late 60s and early 70s there was a rise in dark and gritty cinema tackling the grim subject matter and themes and did not pull their punches. The 1972 John Boorman film Deliverance was one of them, a horrifically interesting film.Four friends, Lewis (Burt Reynolds), Ed (Jon Voight), Bobby (Ned Beatty) and Drew (Ronny Cox) go to the remote wilderness of the Deep South to canoe down the Cahulawassee River before it flooded by the construction of a dam. But in the sticks the men meet very hostile hillbillies, leading to a horrific sexual assault and all four men to explore their dark sides.Deliverance is a very atmospheric film and it is done by the simplicity of Boorman's direction. He uses plenty of long shots and single takes, letting the power of the acting do the talking. Music is kept to a minimum and it adds to the atmosphere as most of the sounds we hear are nature, making you feel like you are in wild forest and it added to the horror when we see the infamous rape scene. It gave the moment even more power.Deliverance has an great cast and all four lead actors give excellent performances as they play some difficult roles and situations. Lewis is a macho man, a survivalist who is the most independently minded and the man who shares the hillbilly view of independent and love of wildness of the area. Ed is someone who ends up having to explore his dark side during their journey and Drew tries to be the conscience and rational of the group. All four end up having a dark bound, knowing what happened in the woods and their relationship had a very Stephen King esque feel to it.Deliverance was made in the early 70s, a time where hostility to the Vietnam War was high but it was unpopular in American culture to criticise it in film or books. Like a lot of good storytelling a story can be used as a way to subvertly talk about a subject through a different and you can see the Vietnam parallels in this film. The group of men are city men who suffer a culture crash and hostility from the locals, going into a hot forest area with an enemy around them as they try to survive in an onslaught and the war atrocities before the suffering the aftermath on the home front.Added to the Vietnam theme there are themes of manhood, the dark side of human nature that inhabits men, especially when they are alone in the woods and far away from civilisation and even a look at the nature of these communities who isolated and hostile to authority. But the film does have a surreal look to the hill folk with all their deformities and go through the old clichés that everyone in the rural Deep South is inbred. Finally there is even a slight environmental message about the destruction of the dam would course to the valley.Deliverance is an interesting film that was well paced and the dark nature was clearly following the hallmarks of cinema for the period. It is certainly worthy viewing.

Review title: My grainy VHS, I need to upgrade!
Review_body: Four city guys take a canoe trip in remote Georgia but find themselves in danger not just from the river itself but also from the local inbred rednecks. I think that Deliverance is quite possibly the original backwoods survival horror/action thriller, many more were to follow, often in the form as slasher movies. This movie is famous for two scenes in particular, firstly the duelling banjos at the beginning, then the notorious male rape "squeal like a pig" scene. The banjo duel is fantastic, only thing I felt that was that having one of the best parts right at the start set the bar too high for the remainder. Burt Reynolds is great as the macho leader of the group and the actors did their own impressive white water rapids stunts. I'm scoring this 7/10 because I felt that the film was a little too long, I found the last part rather slow, and I watched it on VHS, given a better quality print I would most likely have scored it higher. Oh yes, and the toothless hillbillies really looked the part, very unnerving!

Review title: Jon Voight's Performance Was The Worst Of The Lot
Review_body: Question: Did this film really offer the kind of entertainment that American and Canadian movie-goers wanted to see back in 1972? Answer: Yes. It would seem so. And proof of that is here in one plain fact - Deliverance was made on a modest budget of just $2 million and yet it grossed over $46 million at the box-office in its first year, alone.I guess its phenomenal popularity all came down to Deliverance being the very first mainstream film to ever show a homosexual (a hillbilly homosexual, that is) being killed.And that, I guess, gave many movie-goers the greatest pleasure and satisfaction in being witness to that.I mean, otherwise - What else could it be that attracted such a large audience to sit through this tiresome picture and then, afterwards, praise it with glowing approval? *Note* - Deliverance also lost some significant points for exploiting "real-life" human deformity (aka. the inbred hillbillies) solely for the sake of idle entertainment. (Yes. Those "freaks" we see were real people, sans make-up effects)

Review title: If you go down in the woods today..............
Review_body: Together with the mighty "Sharky's Machine","Deliverance" marks the highpoint of Mr Burt Reynolds' career.He is - as someone once rather unkindly said of Miss Diana Dors - forgotten but not gone. As Lewis,the All-American outdoor man he takes on a role that is meat and drink to him,he does all his own stunts and would probably have had his own leg broken if the director had asked him nicely. "Deliverance" tells the story of what happens when he and some friends take a trip to a remote part of the American wilderness.But beware, "Three men in a boat" it isn't. If I was a Hillbilly I would be unhappy about the way my community has been treated by Hollywood over the years.When did you last see a Hillbilly with gleaming white teeth for instance?When I see yet another Billy just a pickin' and a grinnin' the message it gives me is that stereotypical racial images are not helpful.If Mountain People choose to live in totally separate communities isolated from the rest of the U.S. and obeying no laws but their own then that is their right under the Constitution.Burt and his friends should have stayed in Atlanta because getting off the beaten track in Georgia can be a pain in the arse. "Deliverance" is a truly frightening film about a part of the world's largest Democracy where the restraints governing normal human social behaviour do not operate.The message it delivers is bleak :-if you go down in the woods today you're sure of a big surprise..............

"Deliverance," seems to me, to be a movie that audiences and critics may surely avoid today, based on that scene. Yes, that scene I'm talking about where Bobby (Ned Beatty) is forced to strip down to his underwear, and shortly after, is raped by a snarling, toothless hillbilly who seeks to dominate the cowering and frightened city man ("I'm gonna make you squeal like a pig. Weeeeeeeeee!"). This scene and others like it make up one of the most disturbing films about human brutality ever captured on celluloid. The plot: four Atlanta businessmen (Burt Reynolds, Jon Voight, Ronny Cox, and the aforementioned Beatty) take a canoing trip on the Appalachian river. Things get ugly when that scene rolls around, when the four men encounter two bloodthirsty backwoodsmen, and it quickly evolves into an experience none of the men will ever forget. It's a daring feat that John Boorman (who followed this up with the superior 1981 fantasy adventure, "Excalibur") was at the helm of this violent, disturbing thriller that dives deep into what makes man the way he is, and in detailing the line where civilization ends, and "reality" begins. Boorman's film, adapted from James Dickey's novel of the same title, is savage and definitely not for the faint-of-heart.8/10

Amazingly made film, this keeps a strong sense of tone and foreboding going from the first frame to the last. Beautifully shot by Vilmos Zigmond (although a few manipulated day for night shots look a bit wacky). The film moves at an even, moderate pace, without ever hurting the tension or drama. Thematically, it is an examination of the destructive nature of male machismo, the price of survival, the darkness of the human heart, the lies we're willing to tell ourselves and the world to get on, and the split between those of the land and those who use the land. These are not small themes, and sometimes they're a little too on the nose (e.g. dialogue like 'sometimes you have to get lost to find yourself' – although I'm not sure if the film is embracing that platitude or making very dark fun of it). At other times exactly what it's saying seems a bit fuzzy, or like it wants to have all its thematic cakes and eat them too. (Men need to be challenged to find their real self, but – on the other hand – trying to find your 'real self' may be an illusory path to your own destruction, literal or metaphoric). Also, I could see the people of Appalachia, who already carry understandable anger as being constantly portrayed as stupid, inbred and violent, taking offense to the film, and they'd have a point. Yet all that said, this is a movie that's more about a visceral experience than a collage thesis dissection, and that is where 'Deliverance' excels. It takes us to hell, and only partly back, and we get immersed in the journey in a way all too few films pull off. It is quite like being lost in a bad dream. And I mean that as a compliment.

Director: John Boorman
Writers: James Dickey (screenplay), James Dickey (novel)
Stars: Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty , Ronny CoxAdapted for the screen by poet James Dickey from his own novel, the picture follows four city-slicker Southerners during an ill-fated trip down a (fictional) River in the dense wilderness of rural Georgia. Lewis (Burt Reynolds) is the leader of the group because he's a veteran outdoorsman, Ed (Jon Voight) knows his way around the woods but can't match Lewis' wild-man bravado, Drew (Ronny Cox) is a soft-spoken urbanite more comfortable with a banjo than a rifle, and Bobby (Ned Beatty) is an overweight every man along for the ride. Spurred on by Lewis, the men decide to take a canoe trip before the river is dammed to create a lake; for Lewis, the challenge is conquering a disappearing wilderness, and for the others, the kick is escaping the urban grind.Right from the opening frames, Boorman creates an ominous atmosphere, best exemplified by the legendary "Dueling Banjos" scene. Deliverance is hard to watch given the intensity of what happens onscreen, but the acting, film making, and writing are so potent that it's impossible to look away. Accolades showered on the film included Oscar nominations for Best Picture, Best Director, and Best Editing.

In what is arguably the best outdoor adventure film of all time, four city guys confront nature's wrath, in a story of survival. The setting is backwoods Georgia, with its forests, mountains, and wild rivers.The director, John Boorman, chose to use local people, not actors, to portray secondary characters. These locals imbue the film with a depth of characterization unequaled in film history. No central casting "actors" could ever come close to these people's remarkable faces, voices, or actions. I don't recall a film wherein the secondary characters are so realistic and colorful. As much as anything else, it is this gritty realism that makes this film so amazing.Another strength is the film's theme. Nature, in the wild, can be violent. How appropriate that the setting should be the American South. Very few places in the U.S. are, or have been, as violent as redneck country. In a story about Darwinian survival of the fittest, the film conveys the idea that humans are part of nature, not separate from it."Deliverance" is very much a product of its time when, unlike today, Americans expressed concern over a vanishing wilderness. The film's magnificent scenery, the sounds of birds, frogs, crickets, and the roar of the river rapids, combined with the absence of civilization, all convey an environmental message. And that is another strength of the film.At an entertainment level, the tension gradually escalates, as the plot proceeds. Not even half way into the film the tension becomes extreme, and then never lets up, not until the final credits roll. Very few films can sustain that level of intensity over such a long span of plot.Finally, the film's technical quality is topnotch. Direction and editing are flawless. Cinematography is excellent. Dialogue is interesting. And the acting is terrific. Burt Reynolds has never been better. Ned Beatty is perfectly cast and does a fine job. And Jon Voight should have been nominated for an Oscar. If there is a weak link in the film, it is the music, which strikes me as timid.Overall, "Deliverance" almost certainly will appeal to viewers who like outdoor adventure. Even for those who don't, the gritty characterizations, the acting, and the plot tension are reasons enough to watch this film, one of the finest in cinema history.

Review title: The first thing I thought to myself when this ended was 'That's it'
Review_body: Deliverance is another one of those 'classic' films that I just felt no real love for and although it isn't the most overrated 'classic' I've seen and certainly isn't the worst 'classic' I've seen either it still fell well short of my expectations...This film bills itself as a Thriller and therefore I expected a film that provides thrills, tension, intensity and suspense and the reality here is that Deliverance 'delivers' none of these things. The build-up at the start is particularly tedious with Ronny Cox having some weird guitar off with a creepy looking kid - not only was it pointless, but it also went on for far too long. I could have also done without all the nonsense regarding finding people to drive their cars to the other side of the river. It all amounted to unnecessary drawn-out filler which started to get on my nerves.At this point I was still prepared to forgive the film and hoped that it would be a slow-burning film that would become something magnificent, but sadly this was not the case. The first encounter with the hillbillies was quite good and was what I would call mildly suspenseful, but after this scene Deliverance never really became the exciting and tense picture that the film poster suggests it is. In fact, the only really interesting part of the film was the moral debate that the group have about disposing of the body or turning themselves in. This aspect was quite interesting, but perhaps it stood out more for me because of how poor the rest of the film was as a whole.I think the main reason I was disappointed was that I hoped it would be more of a cat and mouse film or a hunt or be hunted type affair, but it doesn't offer the viewer this experience. Rather than being on the edge of my seat, I found myself close to nodding off. It doesn't even work when looked upon as a character building experience as the characters are never really given any development meaning that this film really failed from pretty much every angle.The only good thing about this film were the performances from the four main players (with Ronny Cox and Jon Voight being particularly good) and it was also nice to see Ronny Cox playing a good guy for a change. The acting was very good here and did elevate the film slightly. As a whole though, this film is slow, boring, and basically lacks any real suspense and tension. I've given it a 3 out of 10, but only for the good performances from the principal cast.

Review title: "Sometimes you have to lose yourself before you can find anything."
Review_body: John Boorman's "Deliverance" concerns four suburban Atlanta dwellers who take a ride down the swift waters of the Cahulawassee The river is about to disappear for a dam construction and the flooding of the last untamed stretches of land The four friends emphasize different characters: a virile sports enthusiast who has never been insured in his life since there is no specific risk in it (Burt Reynolds); a passionate family man and a guitar player (Ronny Cox); an overweight bachelor insurance salesman (Ned Beatty); and a quiet, thoughtful married man with a son who loves to smoke his pipe (Jon Voight).What follows is the men's nightmarish explorations against the hostile violence of natureIt is also an ideal code of moral principle about civilized men falling prey to the dark laws of the wilderness Superbly shot, this thrilling adult adventure certainly contains some genuinely gripping scenes

Review title: The most frightening non-horror film ever made.
Review_body: Deliverance is a stunning thriller, every bit as exciting as any good thriller should aspire to be but also stomach-churningly frightening. Though it is not a horror movie, it is just as terrifying as any classic horror film. The very thought of being a normal red-blooded male enjoying an adventure weekend miles from any form of civilisation, only to be captured and sodomised by a couple of violent hillbillies, is surely the worst nightmare of 99.9% of the world's population. It would have been easy for Deliverance to slip into exploitation territory, but John Boorman has cleverly avoided the temptation to go down such a route and has made a film that explores, questions and challenges the very meaning of masculinity. With so many films, you come away wishing to heaven that you could step into the hero's shoes, performing heroic deeds and saving the day and getting the girl.... but with Deliverance, you come away praying to God that you'll never have to experience what these four protagonists go through.Four city guys - Ed (Jon Voight), Lewis (Burt Reynolds), Drew (Ronny Cox) and Bobby (Ned Beatty) - head out into the wilderness to spend a few days canoing down a soon-to-be-dammed river. The guys are riding the rapids in pairs, and Ed and Bobby inadvertently get a little too far ahead of the others so they pull in to the riverside and await their pals in the adjacent woodland. Here, they fall foul of two local woodlanders (Bill McKinney and Herbert Coward), who tie Ed to a tree, while one of them strips and rapes Bobby instructing him, perversely, to "squeal like a pig". Lewis and Drew arrive unseen and Lewis, being a fair archer, kills the rapist while the other hillbilly beats a hasty retreat into the forest. Under great emotional stress, the four canoeists decide to conceal the event and get out of the area. But they find the river increasingly dangerous to negotiate as they journey downstream, and the risk to their lives heightens when the surviving hillbilly returns to take shots at them with his rifle from some unseen vantage point in the rocky cliffs beside the river.Deliverance is very powerful as a survival tale, but even more powerful (and disturbing) as a study of macho attitudes being torn apart and left in humiliated tatters. Though all the performances are remarkable, one must take particular note of Beatty's efforts in a role that many actors would've turned down. The film is very similar thematically to the 1971 film Straw Dogs - both films deal with terrifying sexual violence in isolated locales, and in both the eventual violent revenge exacted by the victim does not result in any sense of satisfaction. The backdrop of the rugged countryside in Deliverance is beautiful to look at, but it also adds to the tension by placing the four canoeists in a setting where they are at the mercy of the hillbillies and the landscape, with nobody to rely on other than themselves. This truly is suspenseful film-making at its finest.

Review title: TRULY A MASTERPIECE OF CINEMA & A TERRIFYING SURVIVAL THRILLER
Review_body:
WOW!!! this 70's Classic survival Horror "DELIVERANCE" used to scare the shi# outta me when i was young but it was so exciting & disturbing that i had to buy it on video back then in the 90's.
This beautifully filmed Man vs the Wild is one shocking flick, as our four great actors Burt Reynolds, John Voight, Ned Beatty & Ronny Cox play four City friends on an adventure trip in the wilderness for a fun filled weekend canoeing down a big river in the Georgia Backcountry where they face their worst fears & a fight for survival.
Burt Reynolds R.I.P is fantastic as the tough hunter of the group "Lewis Medlock" a performance that made him an even bigger star back in the 70's!!! Also of course the legendary John Voight gives one of the greatest performances in movie history here as mild mannered "Ed Gentry" who has to overcome his own fears & become a basically a warrior & find his primal rage side to get his revenge on the evil rapist Hillbillies, it's a perfect piece of Acting, an outstanding performance & one that is iconic now.
But all four guys give superb performances & show what happens to men under extreme pressure in an extremely dangerous situation, Ned Beatty gives a heartfelt & extremely terrified performance as the fun loving chubby guy of the group "Bobby Trippe" who becomes the victim of the depraved Rednecks & his rape scene is still so shocking & so disturbing even today, & then there's Ronny Cox as the more timid & tame guy of the group "Drew Ballinger" & these men & there Adventure of Horror will stay with you well after it ends.
The cinematography is gorgeous & we see the backwoods & big waterfalls & the music is excellent, also it's expertly Directed by John Boorman & he's crafted an intense & suspenseful gritty tale of survival that is scary & is pretty much a Horror film really!!!
"DELIVERANCE" is not only one of the best films of the 1970's but it's also one of the greatest movies ever made & is one of the most iconic films in Cinema history, a true CLASSIC.

Review title: Extremely overrated and boring!! Another movie that's dated and overrated!!
Review_body: Burt Reynolds was surprisingly decent in this film but its extremely overrated. A 7.7 REALLY, it has a horrible negative rape scene and then we get a whimpy pay back. The end is ok but extremely predictable. Have no idea why this is rated so high, its probably the old 1 says it's great so everyone follows so they dont look stupid. In reality you look stupid for saying great film, it's a VERY basic movie with basic acting performances. Watch taken, or murder in the first or green mile skip this bore ass overrated film.

I expected this to be a fun adventure but it turned out to be another traumatizing experience (double feature with Murmur of the Heart wasn't a good idea). The movie dragged at the beginning and I wasn't really invested into it until that moment came and I was like what is happeningggg??? Then I loved everything after that, especially the whole cover up. Also, all of the performances are really great!

Deliverance is an excellent outdoor thriller about survival directed by John Boorman, of which is one of my favorite of his work (along with Excalibur). This film has a great ensemble cast of fantastic actors that includes Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox. The film has these dudes going on a canoeing/camping trip in the soon to extinct Cahulawassee River, intact before it gets expanded and turns into a lake. However, these "city boys" did not make a good impression with the locals, in which provokes an unpleasant confrontation between our main characters and backwoods hillbillies. One of which is played by Bill Mc Kinney who is an excellent villan and also will go on to play as Captain "Red legs" in one of my favorite westerns The Outlaw Josey Wales. The outdoor locations are photographed beautifully and the film is tense, violent and handled in a very realistic and gritty manner. Acting performances are second to none, Burt Reynolds in paticular was awesome. He is criminally underated as a actor, as much as I like Smokey And The Bandit, he should have made less movies like that and more movies like Deliverance. Anyways, Deliverance is an excellent film, that all the way around is very engrossing as a story and very powerful and well made.

and this IS a very disturbing film. I may be wrong, but this is the last film where I considered Burt Reynolds an actual actor, who transformed the role, and delivered a message.Jon Voight and Ned Beatty are also excellent. They are unassuming and unaware; businessmen wanting to enjoy the country. Little did they know what would happen next.The photography and sets are realistic and natural. This was before the days of Wes Craven.What is most disturbing about this film is the fact that places like this still exist. In America, country folk still detest city people; it is almost a century and a half since the Civil War.You will enjoy this film. It was filmed in the rural sections of South Georgia, which still exist. Just don't drive past that to Mobile, Alabama; That area still has not been repaired since Hurricane Katrina. 10/10.addendum: This is also a rare film that stands the test of time, watch it again, you will be interested in the subtle message.

Review title: a different kind of "male bonding" film
Review_body: "Deliverance" is a rollicking thriller, an absorbing moral drama, and an effective commentary on man battling technology, nature, and very real human monsters.  It's the story of four relatively well-adjusted suburbanites who go on a canoe trip out in the boondocks one weekend, only to be accosted by a duo of inbred sodomites who quickly turn their relaxation and peace into a quest for survival.  The idea of humans being degraded to the level of savages, and man battling to survive in a world that's being overtaken by technology are just a few of the poignant themes contained within James Dickey's script.  "Deliverance" isn't for all tastes, but those looking for an intense, well-directed drama will be taken on an unforgettable ride.  And don't forget to "put on your life jacket!"7/10

The 1960s and 70s saw a lot more wild, outdoor pictures, partly because of improvements to cinematography and more mobile equipment opened up greater possibilities and lessened the need for studio shooting, but also partly because the hippy era resulted in a lot of movies with a "getting-back-to-nature" vibe. But this was also an age of questioning and uncertainty, and the wilderness could also be turned into a place of terror and mystery. This mixture of yearning and fear provides the backdrop for 1972 thriller Deliverance.Deliverance was the breakthrough movie for English director John Boorman. Boorman's earliest pictures had been very overtly stylised, with lots of zooms and rapid editing. For Deliverance he has a more subtle approach, but still with that strong sense of rhythm and atmosphere. Of especial note in Deliverance is his use of space on the river. Every shot shows a tight bend or is part obscured by the trees – we never really get a look at the way ahead. This is not an Aguirre/Apocalypse Now vision of the river as a road wending its way through the forest. This is the river as a maze where every part looks the same and there doesn't seem to be any way out. This greatly helps to fuel the sense of confusion and paranoia that permeates the whole thing. But Boorman further remembers to keep this a human drama, staging a lot of the action in close-up with the background an unfocused blur.This is all the better to capture some fine acting. Burt Reynolds is, at first glance, simply a macho poser, albeit a very charismatic one. But there is more going on in his performance, with hints of disturbing capabilities just below the surface. Ned Beatty impresses in his first screen role, allowing himself to be totally humiliated and still appearing believable in his reactions. On the downside Ronny Cox is hammy and Jon Voigt is a little overwrought. Towards the end there's a neat cameo by source novel author James Hickey, giving an understated but menacing turn as the local sheriff.Like so many pictures of this era, Deliverance states its themes boldly. There is the conflict between progress and rural simplicity, and the need for men to prove themselves in an age where technology has made everything easy and comfortable. Such statements seem a little trite, but in the case of Deliverance they are forgivable because they are presented in such a taut, compelling thriller, with layers of ambiguity that are cunning yet never convoluted, and certainly never pretentious. It is neither as grandiose or other-worldly as Heart of Darkness or its many adaptations (including Apocalypse Now), but is instead close, gritty and uncomfortably lifelike, even when at its most nightmarish.

Shot in the beautiful nature this tragic story passes us. Four friends go on a canoe trip deep in the woods. On their way they have some trouble with locals and what was supposed to be a beautiful and exciting journey turns out to be a disaster.The four friends are played by Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox. They all are good in their roles, especially Burt Reynolds as the cool guy. There are some very disturbing scenes, one with Ned Beatty in particular, but they work the way they were meant. A haunting but very good story against beautiful nature, even more beautifully shot. Only the cinematography of the river and the woods is worth the watch, if you can stand the violence that does occur.

Review title: A Lighthearted Fun Romp With Georgia's Finest People
Review_body: Deliverance not only stood the test of time, but it conquered it, and with a good restoration that is much needed (come on Criterion!) this film easily earns its title as a classic movie. It's a disturbing and anxiety ridden survival adventure story, filled with excitement and horror, a movie that will linger in the minds of viewers for as long as this film has been around. It's truly sensational when a film that's in it's fifth decade can still form a lasting, haunting impact on the audience, showing man facing the horrors of nature, themselves, and deconstructed masculinity, Deliverance opened the door for many writers and filmmakers to explore these traits and environments, but none can match the evocative atmospheric intensity as Deliverance.

Review title: A harrowing and still one-of-a-kind meditation on civilization vs. primitive human instinct
Review_body: Director John Boorman's cinematic masterpiece is at once an exciting and harrowing thriller, while also a fascinating meditation on the nature of civilization and human nature's more primal instincts. Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty, and Ronny Cox plan to get back to nature by canoeing down the fictional Cahulawassee River before it's damed up and flooded, marring it's wild natural beauty. These four cityfolk run the spectrum of macho outdoorsman Reynolds to the soft "born salesman" Beatty. On their trip, the four find themselves running afoul some seriously creepy hillfolk (which is putting it mildly if you've seen the film or know what happens). Without spoiling anything, the four are pushed to their limits both by nature and the menacing mountain men. "Deliverance" was based on a novel and adapted by it's author, James Dickey. Thematically, the film most interesting in that it doesn't solidly land on one side or the other when it comes to whether civilization or the primitive is more superior to the other, but instead the story finds it's strongest character in Voight, who falls solidly between not being too civilized or too primitive. The theme of encroaching civilization weakening our stronger primal elements is something that would have been perfectly aligned with director Sam Peckinpah, who was Dickey's first choice for director for this film. Boorman is an fine director ("Point Blank" "Excalibur" "The Emerald Forest"), but I can't help but image what kind of a viscerally resonant film Peckinpah would have made, combining the most interesting elements he explored in "Ride the High Country," "The Wild Bunch," and "Straw Dogs." Also of note is the gorgeous photography by Vilmos Zsigmond ("The Deer Hunter" "Close Encounter" "Blow Out), outside of some poorly done day-for-night-photography during a cliff climbing sequence. Overall, "Deliverance" is a smart film that engaging on both a entertainment and intellectual level. A true classic, even if it might have been better with Peckinpah at the helm.

The movie begins with four men planning to go for a trip in a ravaged river, considering the river is on borrowed time. Main characters, in a first sight, aren't anything special or remarkable from each other-- maybe with exception of Lewis, who seems to be an aggressive man. Once they enter the river, they face two local inhabitants that feel like raping them for no apparently reason-- which was probably an inspiration for Wes Craven in 77's "The Hills Have Eyes". After the raping indeed happens, lots of bad things happen to the main characters, making it hard to not feel impressed with those scenes. Most of the tension is created by the strong direction John Boorman gives us; he focuses on the character's feelings, followed by a bunch of unforeseen situations they've been into, like the leg breaking, the dangerous escalade, among others. After they talk to the police, it seems like they're all going to be caught by the cops, since they are all lying. Those scenes were also tense, and I'm very thankful they finally got away with murder in the end. "Deliverance" is one of the most tense films I've seen, and probably one of the best of the 70's. It's well worth your time, believe me!

Review title: It's more than just the theme music...
Review_body: In honor of the late Burt Reynolds' passing today, it's time to revisit some of his classic films, starting with Deliverance, you know, the movie with the famous banjo tune. Released during the new hollywood era, this film became a huge success for Warner Bros and its parent company, Warner Communications, which was formed in 1972 after former parent Kinney sold off its entertainment assets after a parking scandal.

"Deliverance" is often seen as a shocker, but that's really sort of a hasty conclusion. Yeah, at one point Ned Beatty gets savagely raped by some rednecks, but that's one brief scene in 110 minutes. The rape is entirely implied anyway (thank God), so the uproar when the movie came out was sorta ridiculous and makes me wonder if the protesters had even seen the movie. "Deliverance" is actually just an entertaining adventure movie with a solid story, great actors and some really beautiful scenery. Some are destined to make it into a groundbreaking classic, some are destined to pass it of as a one-dimensional exploitation picture, but really it's neither. For a movie that's still often marketed as disturbing, I really found it remarkably inoffensive. Maybe inoffensive isn't an incredibly positive quality, but "Deliverance" isn't an incredibly good movie either. I still like it though, I just don't love it.

Review title: Watch it for the excellent acting, the great story and the nice photography...
Review_body: Only a couple of weeks ago I saw "Without a Paddle". Now you probably ask yourself what that has to do with this movie. Well, a lot more than you might expect because "Deliverance" isn't a comedy like the other one is, but the entire story is pretty similar. Both are adventure movies in which a couple of friends go on a canoing trip in the middle of nowhere, where they will find themselves in some dangerous situations. But the main difference between the two is that this one was made for an adult audience and that "Without A Paddle" is intended for teenagers. And it shows. While "Deliverance" is a very nice movie, "Without a Paddle" certainly isn't...Deliverance tells the story of four men from the city who want to canoe down the Cahulawassee River, which soon will be lost because the entire surroundings will be flooded once the construction of a nearby dam is finished. At first it all seems to be an idyllic and adventurous trip through some magnificent landscapes, but soon they get more than they bargained for. They already met the local population at the village where they started the trip and at first they all seemed rather retarded, but nice. But once they are in the middle of nowhere, the locals become more and more of a threat...I've seen about four hundred movies the past 10 months, but I don't think there is any movie from which I'll still recognize the music after a couple of weeks, except for this one. The song 'The Duelling Banjos' in the beginning is not only very captivating and hard to resist, it's probably one of the best known movie songs ever. But not only the music is nice, so are the entire story, the acting and the photography...The story is so good because it is plausible. It isn't difficult to make an overly dramatic, but unbelievable movie with this story line, but the makers have avoided that trap perfectly. What they have done is portraying a threatening situation in such a good way, that you'll be sitting on the edge of your seat from the moment all misery starts. And when it is all over, you're glad that you weren't the one that had to deal with it all. That's of course also thanks to the excellent performances by the four leads. Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox all play their roles so well that you immediately forget that you're watching some well known actors. I might even say that these were probably the very best roles of their lives. Especially Burt Reynolds has never been better than in this movie.All in all this is a classic that shouldn't be missed. In these days you get to see such bad movies that you start wondering if Hollywood has always made such awful things. The answer is no, just check movies like this one and be convinced that they once used to make some very classy productions that are able to keep you focused from the first moment till the last. I give it an 8/10.

I'm surprised this film averages a relatively paltry 7.9 on the rating scale; it's just about peerless in my opinion as a horror movie, with the ill-fated quartet (Voight, Reynolds, Beatty and Cox) canoeing down a river marked for imminent landfill whose idyllic sojourn turns to chaos when Beatty is violently attacked by a pair of mountain men.Voight is established as a bit of a fence-sitter, essentially living vicariously through the macho Reynolds, an abrasive if likable rogue living dangerously for kicks. The naturalist Cox - the solitary figure - laments the industrialisation of the planet and representing the industrialist, Beatty struggles to adapt to the demands of the wild without civilised boundaries for protection. McKinney and Coward in brief but terrifying roles are the epitome of the outback villain, their opportunistic crimes brutal and merciless.While its easy to focus on the film's immortal scene, the pig reference from which is now oft quoted, for me the penultimate moment in the film happens when Voight attempts to shoot a deer, revealing the innate weakness he's subsequently compelled to overcome in the true test of survival. Great atmosphere, score ("Duelling Banjos") and several chilling moments guarantee a classic that should transcend time and imitations ("The River Wild" comes to mind). It's just a shame that director Boorman didn't do more in his sparse career.

Review title: Still A Match For Modern Psycho-Thrillers
Review_body: A comparatively old movie, now; originating from way back in 1971. But 40 years have hardly phased its capacity to make viewers shudder.Comfortable urban America seems to harbour some dread of things going haywire in the wilderness. Probably a hang-over from the days of Indian conflict. Here its the white tribes: isolated hillbillies and their inbreeding, and a complete absence of civilised conduct. Our four heroes take the adventure holiday from hell, as their sojourn in the wilds takes on a very grim aspect indeed.The movie stars Burt Reynolds in an unusually straight role, played with a very keen edge. Jon Voight, soon after his success in 'Midnight Cowboy', still manages to look outwardly vulnerable, but is ultimately proved to be the real survivor. Ned Beatty always gives an excellent B-list return, whilst an unassuming Ronny Cox makes up the quartet. They really do look like 4 mix-n-match friends out for a good time that never happens.Filming highlights the wilderness to amazing effect. It looks gloriously expansive, violently dramatic, and frighteningly claustrophobic by turns as the story moves forward from fun adventure to bitter survival. The sense of loss and isolation is perfectly realised. The comfortably familiar becomes strange and threatening.And whilst all of this is going forward, there is the idealised evaluation of minds raised to comply with rules, accept moral tenets, and endeavour to see a broader responsibility beyond the immediacy of survival that raises 'Deliverance' above the similarly themed 'Southern Comfort'.Well worth a watch, though at times it still makes very uncomfortable viewing. It was nominated for 3 Oscars, and was probably denied them on account of its subject matter. Horror-thrillers tend to be dismissed by academic and art-house selection.One thing's for certain; you'll remember this minutely-observed small cast of characters and their complex plight, long after the CGI hoards of epics like 'Rings' have become an incomprehensible montage.

"Deliverance" is one of those films that is mainly remembered today for one particularly iconic scene. The 'squeal like a pig' scene does for hillbillies what "Jaws" did for sharks but the film has more depth than this infamous scene might lead you to believe.The story is based on the best-selling first novel of James Dickey, who was already a renowned poet. The story sports a certain poetic flavour with the exploration of themes such as the glory of nature and man's attempted conquest of it.The plot concerns a group of four friends who embark upon a canoeing trip down the Cahulawassee River in the Georgia backwoods. While the wild river poses a certain degree of danger these men soon find that the locals are more dangerous by far.The cast is a pretty good one with the best performance coming from the versatile Jon Voight. Burt Reynolds is a good fit as the leader of the group while Ned Beatty & Ronny Cox make convincing everymen. Special note goes to the actors playing the various mountain men since they manage to give the film an air of authenticity.John Boorman's direction is well-handled and was rewarded with an Oscar nomination. The film looks attractive throughout and also features some memorable music, most notably "Duelling Banjos".Ultimately, I consider the film a well-executed thriller with plenty of depth. The notoriety of the film's single most famous scene may lead you to believe that it is otherwise unremarkable but that's not the case at all.

Review title: This is why I watch movies .....
Review_body: It is to discover movies like Deliverance that I watch movies. There are so few of them. So few of them that talk to you. And turn into your best friends. You can put them on when you have a bad day. And they talk to you if you are a guy like me. A guy who has no friends and depends on art to keep him going.Three squares led by a survivalist heads to rural America in search of adventure. They get more than they bargained for. But in the process, some of them become better men. Deliverance is one of the best survival flicks of all time. Yes, greater than Alien and The Naked Prey.It is amazing how American movies speak to the whole world. They speak everyone's language and appeal to people from all cultures. I am sure movie fans from all earth alienated countries would be able to identify with Deliverance.I recommend the book by James Dickey. It is amazing how John Boorman added elements to Dickey's novel to convert it into a novel. The guitar duel scene must rank as one of the greatest scenes ever put on film. Marlon Brando must have kicked himself for turning down Reynolds role. I thought Ned Beatty was excellent in this film.

New on the Fox Network: When Good Movies Go Bad!Or, a review of John Boorman's 1972 film Deliverance, which he produced and directed, based upon James Dickey's 1970 novel of the same name. Dickey also wrote the screenplay, which explains a lot, especially if you are familiar with his 'poetry.' The actual look of the film, however, is sensational. The cinematography of nature, by Vilmos Zsigmond, is still stunning after thirty-five years- especially those scenes shot in twilight, dusk, and night, and the first forty-five or so minutes sets the basis of a good tale which could have been something really special. Then, Dickey digs into his own personal bag of fetishes (his most famous poem is The Sheep Child, about bestiality) and latencies and the film becomes an almost nonstop stream of a narrative propelled by the Dumbest Possible Action theory of film.Although the coinage of that term arrived a few years later than this film, Deliverance is as fine an example of that genre as there is. The term arrived in the early 1980s, when a spate of slasher films from the Halloween to the Nightmare On Elm Street to the Friday The 13th series, to their even cheaper knockoffs, were always dependent upon the early success of their villains stemming from the utter stupidity of their victims, to wit: big breasted cheerleader is alone in a dark house, hears a scream from down an even darker hallway, yet rushes headlong toward the scream, all the while knowing that a serial killer is lurking about. In similar fashion, this film goes from a realistic portrayal of masculine mores to a silly, unrealistic, A to B to C pointless film. The turning point comes when one of the four male leads is sodomized forcefully by a hillbilly and his toothless gun-toting crony. the film finally founders because it lacks real situations, characters, and philosophy. After all, it's difficult to get truly philosophic after a character's been torpedoed by a hillbilly, and so a film that could have been a realistic and philosophic exploration of characters, and male character, devolves into a ridiculous melodrama of revenge, deceit, and perversion. Boorman is a noted filmmaker, but he's never been considered one of the great auteurs, and a film like Deliverance shows why. Some have accused me of gleeing in bad art. I don't. But needling the bad is a palliative over the depression bad art brings.
